skill.name: css-development:validate
skill.description: This skill should be used when reviewing or auditing existing CSS code for consistency with established patterns. Triggers on "review CSS", "audit styles", "check CSS", "validate stylesheet", "CSS review". Checks semantic naming, dark mode coverage, Tailwind usage, and test coverage.

skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no code execution capabilities. Only reads CSS files for validation as stated in its purpose. No network, filesystem write, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: CSS validation requires manual review of semantic naming, dark mode coverage, and Tailwind composition. This skill automates pattern checking and generates actionable reports with file and line references.
actual_capabilities: Reviews CSS files for semantic class naming conventions
Checks dark mode variant coverage on colored elements
Identifies missing test coverage for CSS classes
Flags missing documentation comments on classes
Generates structured validation reports with file:line references
limitations: Does not modify CSS files automatically
Does not validate CSS syntax or browser compatibility
Does not execute or test rendered styles
Requires user to specify CSS files for review

use_cases.title: Pre-merge code review
use_cases.description: Validate CSS before merging to ensure pattern consistency across the codebase.

use_cases.title: Technical debt assessment
use_cases.description: Audit existing CSS for dark mode gaps and naming issues across the entire codebase.

use_cases.title: Pattern enforcement
use_cases.description: Verify contributors follow established CSS patterns during code review process.

prompt_templates.title: Basic validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Validate the CSS in styles/components.css against established patterns. Check semantic naming, dark mode coverage, and Tailwind @apply usage.

prompt_templates.title: Focused check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check all CSS files for missing dark mode variants on colored elements. List each class missing dark: variants with file:line references.

prompt_templates.title: Naming review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review CSS class names for non-semantic naming. Flag utility-based names like .btn-blue or .text-big and suggest semantic alternatives.

prompt_templates.title: Full audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Run full CSS validation: check semantic naming, dark mode coverage, @apply usage, test coverage, and documentation. Provide summary with priority recommendations.

output: Issues: 3 high priority (missing dark mode), 4 medium (naming)
Example issues: .card-header missing dark mode (line 45), .btn-blue should be .button-secondary

best_practices: Specify the exact CSS file path to validate for focused results
Review dark mode issues first as they cause visual bugs
Use validation reports before refactoring to understand scope
anti_patterns: Using utility class names like .btn-blue or .text-big
Missing dark: variants on background and text colors
Scattered Tailwind utilities in markup instead of @apply composition

faq.question: Can this skill modify CSS files?
faq.answer: No. This skill only validates and reports issues. Use css-development:refactor skill to automatically fix problems.

faq.question: What CSS files does it check?
faq.answer: It reads any CSS files you specify. Common paths include styles/components.css and component-specific stylesheets.

faq.question: Does it test rendered styles in browser?
faq.answer: No. It validates static CSS patterns only. Browser rendering tests require separate test files.

faq.question: Is data from my CSS files sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill runs locally and only reads files to provide validation feedback within your session.

faq.question: Why are some classes flagged as non-semantic?
faq.answer: Non-semantic names like .btn-blue describe appearance rather than purpose. Use names like .button-primary that describe what the element is.

faq.question: How does this differ from css-development:refactor?
faq.answer: Validate reviews and reports issues. Refactor actually modifies code. Use validate first to understand scope, then refactor to fix.
